title: SAPHARI - Safe and Autonomous Physical Human-Aware Robot Interaction

author: Alessandro De Luca, Department of Computer and System Sciences Antonio Ruberti, Sapienza University of Rome

segmentation: So this project just started.
I'm the coordinator from the University of Roma Sapienza.
It's.
Code 7 IP project and these are the partners.
There are 10 + 2 third parties and our team plays.
If you're familiar with soccer 442, so we are for research institution for universities and two industrial partners.
But we are also divided by countries, three countries for partners from Germany, for from Italian to from France.
I don't know if you've as coordinator you have seen this recent diagrams.
We place ourselves in this classification under robotic coworkers project an our sector of interest is both industrial and professional service.
So what is all about Safari?
So this trip is intended to have coworkers working in real application.

Both of the industrial type and professional service where we want to merge safe physical human robot interaction with reactivity based on some cognitive information, and we use as a technology soft robotics in the sense of compliant devices.
With respect to the objective, we are addressing safety issues, sufficiency, of course, robustness with respect to real world condition and ease of use.
By the end users.
So.
The main concept gravitates around several basic topics or going from the megatronic part, so the design of variable impedance devices and of upper limb Robert system safety issues.
Indeed, perception of the environment and real time processing, task planning, and re planning.
Being aware of the human, sharing the workspace with robots and then interaction control, mainly physical interaction.
With a series of reactive action that we have to generate in real time based on what we learned about how the robot behaves, how the human behaves when they are collaborating for a useful task.
So these are the highlights I just will present a couple of them.
Certainly we want to end up with a Handbook of human injury in robotics like in the automotive industry.
How safe or unsafe are this robot the strategy for keeping safety as a primary objective and then possibly come out with recommendation for the ongoing new safety standards?
The whole concerns and believe that the next generation of robots will be based on the variable impedance actuation technology.
If you know what it is so.
The project will develop more freedom upper bodies, so certainly lightweight because this reduced.
Possibility of injuries compliant but also energy efficient and as performant as conventional rigid robot arms.
There are control issue based on the sensor information but also on model based.
I will detail a little bit this more recent work that we started on combined collision avoidance detection and reaction strategies.
Of course we have to monitor the workspaces, they may be very large but also very cluttered in the application.
We have to understand human motion intention, so really physical motion, not cognitive.
In this sense we have to understand which part of the human body and which part of the robot body should collaborate.
So interact physically with exchange of forces.
We learn Robert Motion and we have this concept of reactive action generation.
So this is part of the ease of use but also for further development of application.
Where you have elementary action and I will show you some of them and you have to decide which action to activate in real time.
When you deviate from a nominal plan because of some information gathered by your sensor.
The nominal plan should be aware of the presence of the human, so we have a work package devoted to this.
What we call safe and legible motion or task.
So we have an IP project.

This is so we are doing basic research and basic development, but we are driven by use cases and we have three use cases, two other industrial type, one at the robot manufacturer Kuka itself, which is also a partner.
One of the ideas France, an assembly of our plane.
Another more playground.
Let's say offer research which is a hospital or laboratory environment.
Where daily activities has to be performed by trained nurse and one or more manipulator arms.
So.
Starting from the basic, this is the development of the variable impedance technology and it goes through project so you can see on the last column what we plan to do in Safari.

So upper limbs of different technology including also variations so we can online change the stiffness or the damping of the structure, or the whole impedance including also a change of apparent inertia.
One particular things that I want to point out is that the group of Pisa is developing a very low cost modular variable stiffness device that can be combined with.
Interconnection element and it's provided to the Member of the consortium but also outside in our open hardware software policy, so you can redesign the things by yourself or just by the.
Complete product and then assembly and you have all the documentation.
The purpose is to have a community built and if you don't know what is all about this variable stiffness you can think about 1 degree of freedom.
So adjoint of robot with two Motors and you can simultaneously control the motion of the link but also the stiffness of this joint.
Of course combining multiple degrees of freedom.
Activation of this kind you can have changing stiffness at the end effector level or at any level in the robot structure.
And this is 1 first assembly with this.
Elements this is called QQ Mate.
You can throw things actually you can show that you can be much more energy efficient.
And you can play drum enough like.
Ringo Starr, but I mean it, can be also quite robust and this is low cost SO11 component of this is supposed to cost about 300 euros.
And this is a high end product.
This is developed by the LRS.
I don't know, you probably have seen this before, so it's human like insides.
It's compliant at all joints, including from the arm and the finger.
It's quite robust, you can.
You can hit it so it's not just safety for the human side because it's lightweight and compliant, but it's also safe from the robot side, and it's.
Here it's an application.
This is good research.
Usually you have a hammer and you look for a nail.
But this is really we have to hammer and we can do this only thanks to the compliant behavior and then you have also safety.
Here you have collision detection and reaction.
The arm just stops without using external sensing.
OK this is only with internal sensors an.
The.
This is just to remind you what do you mean by human aware planning.
This is just a multi degree of freedom robot.
This is Justin with a mobile based just bringing a Cup to a user an if.
Of course it should be in a very natural way an you can program this.
The challenge here is that we have to replan when needed.
Such kind of motion in quasi real time.
So let's say 2 three milliseconds.
We have one component of the project which learns motion.
I mean you can acquired from.
Human motion, imitation and then you can refine your task by kinesthetic activity.
So learning both motion and interaction forces that are needed to do the task, and this can happen at any contact level along the structure.
So this is past work.
I don't know if you're from, I mean it's a starting point, so this is a system where you can detect collision without any sensor.
No surface sensor, no camera, nothing at all.
In principle you can also avoid to use joint torque measurement and this is the famous Sammy Aberdeen testing on itself, the capability of reacting and stopping.
You can do you have a list of strategies available for doing that.
I always say that you should not repeat what he has done here.
I mean this is still critical.

So safety comes from the bottom from the mechanic, from the control from the redundant Sensory System Co existence is when human and robot are sharing the workspace but not really doing something together.
Collaboration is when you search intentional contact OK and you have to exchange forces in order to perform a task and this is driven by the application of assembly.
For instance in the aircraft industry.
And here.
I have some recent results where you can see at least collision avoidance and some preliminary form of collaboration.
Indeed, you have one basic task which requires some more cognitive issues is.

To say I don't know if you're familiar with this lighting statement, say, give me the strength to sustain what I cannot change, give me the power to change what I can and give me the knowledge to understand which is the case and is exactly this is one goal of our project because we have two separate undesired collision from intentional contact from the user an from the robot side.
So here you see the robots doing some task in the Cartesian space.
But avoiding collision, this is the whole story.
You can do this with very cheap sensors like the Kinect.
You can do this whole body.
And.
The second part of the video, of course you're using here the redundant degrees of freedom of this arm.
The task is only positional based, so you have three components which specify the end effector.
You have 7 degrees of freedom, so you have a lot of redundancy, and here is the collaboration phase where you seek for a contact that in this case only at the end effector level.
But we foresee to have this contact occurs at any place along the structure, and to recognize if it's a collision or if it's unintended contact.
And of course, why doing this collaboration?
So searching for the contact you tend to avoid further obstacles so you monitor continuously the occurrence of.
The environment itself.
OK, I think I can skip this.

So we have seen that we have a lot of kind of reaction capability, so we can classify this in elementary action and we have to set up an architecture which is able to search in this kind of graph of possibility.
What is the best next action that you have to activate once you recognize that you're going off the nominal plan?
OK, so this is the framework of action generation patterns and I will show you just.
A couple of
Video that illustrates this concept.
This is a simple task.
It's just a point to point motion along a straight line.
And you program to move Robert Eddie from .1 to .2.
This is the normal operation with Cartesian impedance only.
So if you have a contact, just deviate slightly, then you specify additional action to be activated.
For instance here collision avoidance.
So it goes really away from the path and tries to get back to the original task as soon as possible.
Or you can scale the trajectory.
So without modifying the path but just the timing of motion.
Or just have.
Torque control so you can move around the robot and then reactivate the original task by a contact pull command.
And.
This is a more complete scenario where you can see the different modality where you by which you can track the environment.
So with different sensor you can also include an understanding of the motion of the user for the robot.
You have also this interface.
It's a very simple interface, but what is important here is required.
Also contact so you just push on the robot at certain places and you understand what he has to do next and then activate one of these action from all this situation.
OK, I'm done, just because I'm a console guy.
Just wanted to point out and I've seen that many of you are using the Kuka lightweight arm, but there are still basic control issue here.
For instance, on this side we have an extra maximum payload imposed and we have done problem of vibration.
So we have to control this accurately.
Remember that this is compliant.
It's not variable compliant, but indeed we want to have the same performance of a fully rigid arm when needed, and then this is another aspect.
Impedance control at the end effector level is implemented here.
You have selective compliance here, is very oscillatory and more stiff in the horizontal direction.
What we want to do is to have this kind of behavior in multiple points depending on the task, like a whole arm manipulation and how do you design this force control and impedance control at this lab.
So thank you.
